@thetrevorpotter, president of @CampaignLegal, said ‚ÄúIt is basic decency to allow voters to receive water from nonpartisan volunteers ... Senator @ossoff‚Äôs bill would protect voters in line from being forced to choose between their right to vote & their fundamental human needs."

‚ÄúAs we waited in line for hours, through the rain, we were appreciative of the kind volunteers offering all of us something to drink,‚Äù Zwang said. ‚ÄúWe saw some voters leave because of the long lines, but the offer of something to drink helped many of us wait.‚Äù

Jason Zwang & his wife, who live in Peoplestown, waited a combined 7 hours to vote. While waiting, nonpartisan vols offered them water & food while standing in line on a hot, rainy day.

Under SB 202, vols could face up to a year in prison for trying to offer a bottle of water.

‚ÄúNo voter should be made to wait hours in line to vote,‚Äù Cottman said. ‚ÄúBut when long lines happen, all voters deserve access to water while they wait. To criminalize that is outrageous ‚Äî and I‚Äôm grateful to Senator @ossoff and @SenatorWarnock for introducing this bill.‚Äù

Aiyana Cottman, from Atlanta, waited nearly four hours to vote in 2020.

While waiting, she saw nonpartisan volunteers offering water to those who were waiting, and her experience that day inspired her to sign-up to be a poll worker.

"Fair Fight Action is proud to support this legislation, and I am proud that Georgia's Democratic Congressional delegation is leading to protect access to the ballot box for all eligible Americans,‚Äù said @staceyabrams, Founder of @fairfightaction.

‚ÄúThe Voters‚Äô Access to Water Act gets us closer to that goal, and I‚Äôm proud to work with Senator @ossoff to get this important legislation, along with the critical For the People Act, over the finish line," @SenatorWarnock continued.

‚ÄúVoting rights are preservative of all other rights. We must do everything in our power to expand access to the ballot box, and eliminate any and all barriers that will make it harder for voters in Georgia and nationwide to make their voices heard,‚Äù @SenatorWarnock said.

‚ÄúGeorgia voters are often made to wait hours in line to vote. This bill will ensure a nonpartisan, Good Samaritan volunteer can offer voters in line a bottle of water without fear of criminal prosecution,‚Äù Sen. @ossoff said while introducing the legislation.

The "Voters‚Äô Access to Water Act" would prohibit states from banning the provision of food or water to voters waiting in line ‚Äî as long as volunteers do not engage in campaigning or political activity ‚Äî and as long as water or food are offered to every voter in line.

Yesterday, Sen. @ossoff & @SenatorWarnock officially introduced the "Voters' Access to Water Act," which protects voters‚Äô access to water when they are made to wait in line outside polling places.

This is in response to GA SB 202, which *criminalizes* offering voters water. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E1Hi3H1XoAQEv1b.jpg

Silence only helps bad actors. Sharing info about attacks, exploits or vulnerabilities allows us to find trends in attacks, share effective responses, and respond effectively to the fast-pace and evolving threat of cyberattack.

In this rapidly evolving environment the federal government has a role to play. To start, 
@CISAgov has tools and resources available to help protect networks (https://cisa.gov/ransomware) and implement best practices (http://cisa.gov/cyber-essentials)
Citizens, companies, and even local and state governments are vulnerable to cyberattacks and need to be prepared in advance to deal with them.

Ransomware has been on the rise for a long time, but increases in teleworking have exposed existing cyber vulnerabilities in many companies‚Äô systems. We see from Colonial Pipeline that such vulnerabilities can impact even the largest companies.

Ransomware is malware that infects a computer system and locks it down, preventing it from working. It holds the system ‚Äúhostage‚Äù until a ransom is paid. Pipelines aren‚Äôt unique; ransomware can target digital records, ordinary servers or even traffic lights.
The first is the rise of ransomware attacks, the second (which I plan to discuss more at a later date) is the vulnerability of critical infrastructure.

While not a replacement for Colonial Pipeline‚Äôs full network, this waiver and several smaller lines that are in operation should buy time to restore full function. This incident illustrates two problems at once.

The attack has caused shutdowns across their network, a problem that is exacerbated by rising demand for fuel as the economy recovers. To help combat supply issues, the Department of Transportation issued a temporary waiver to ease trucking of oil products to impacted areas.
